title: The 10-Complement Rule: When Numbers Cross Column Boundaries
description: Master the soroban 10-complement rule for carrying and borrowing across columns. Comprehensive guide with friends of 10 pairs, step-by-step examples, combined techniques, and expert tips from an occupational therapist mom.

author.name: Amanda Williams
author.role: Pediatric Occupational Therapist & Mother of Three

content.intro: As a pediatric occupational therapist, I've spent 12 years helping children develop fine motor skills and cognitive abilities. When my oldest daughter struggled with carrying and borrowing in second grade, I discovered the soroban - and specifically, the 10-complement rule. What amazed me wasn't just that it worked, but HOW it worked: the physical manipulation of beads across columns made the abstract concept of place value tangible. Now all three of my kids use this technique, and I recommend it to many families in my practice.

sections.text: The 10-complement rule is the soroban technique for handling calculations that cross column boundaries - what traditional math calls 'carrying' (in addition) or 'borrowing' (in subtraction). When a calculation would result in more than 9 in a column or require subtracting more than is available, you use 10-complement to shift value between columns.

The 10-complement is often called 'friends of 10' because it's based on number pairs that always add up to 10. There are nine pairs total, and mastering them is essential for multi-digit calculations.
Unlike 5-complement which has only four pairs, 10-complement has nine pairs to learn. The good news is that they're symmetrical - once you learn half, you automatically know the other half:

From my occupational therapy perspective, the 10-complement addresses one of the biggest hurdles in elementary math: understanding place value and regrouping. When children physically move beads between columns, they're not just memorizing procedures - they're building genuine number sense.

items: Traditional carrying/borrowing is often taught as a memorized procedure without understanding
Children frequently make errors because they don't visualize what's happening
The soroban makes the 'exchange' of 10 ones for 1 ten visible and tangible
This physical experience builds lasting mathematical intuition
Children who learn 10-complement often outperform peers in mental math

sections.text: When adding two numbers would give you more than 9 in a column, you can't show that result on the soroban (each column maxes out at 9). Instead, you carry to the next column. The rule is: ADD 1 to the tens column, SUBTRACT the complement from the ones column.
Think of it as making change: if you have 8 and add 5, you get 13. You can't show 13 in one column, so you 'trade' 10 ones for 1 ten. The complement tells you what's left over.

items: Step 1: Set 8 on the ones column (heaven bead down + 3 earth beads up)
Step 2: Analyze - you want to add 5, but 8 + 5 = 13, which exceeds 9
Step 3: Find the complement - 5's complement is 5 (because 5 + 5 = 10)
Step 4: Execute - Add 1 to tens column, subtract 5 from ones column (8 - 5 = 3)
Step 5: Read result - 13 (1 in tens, 3 in ones)
Step 1: Set 7 on the ones column
Step 2: Analyze - 7 + 6 = 13, exceeds 9
Step 3: Find the complement - 6's complement is 4 (because 6 + 4 = 10)
Step 4: Execute - Add 1 to tens column, subtract 4 from ones column (7 - 4 = 3)
Step 5: Read result - 13

sections.text: When subtracting a number larger than what's in the ones column, you need to borrow from the tens column. The rule is: SUBTRACT 1 from the tens column, ADD the complement to the ones column.

items: Step 1: Set 13 on the soroban (1 in tens, 3 in ones)
Step 2: Analyze - you want to subtract 8 from ones, but only 3 is there
Step 3: Find the complement - 8's complement is 2 (because 8 + 2 = 10)
Step 4: Execute - Subtract 1 from tens column, add 2 to ones column (3 + 2 = 5)
Step 5: Read result - 5
Step 1: Set 15 on the soroban (1 in tens, 5 in ones)
Step 2: Analyze - you want to subtract 7 from ones, but only 5 is there
Step 3: Find the complement - 7's complement is 3 (because 7 + 3 = 10)
Step 4: Execute - Subtract 1 from tens column, add 3 to ones column (5 + 3 = 8)
Step 5: Read result - 8

sections.text: This is where it gets interesting - and where many children need extra support. Some problems require BOTH complement techniques in the same calculation. Let's walk through this carefully:

items: Initial: Set 8 (heaven bead + 3 earth beads)
Goal: Add 6, but 8 + 6 = 14 (needs carrying)
10-complement: Add 1 to tens, subtract 4 from ones
But wait: 8 - 4 can't be done directly (only 3 earth beads to remove)
5-complement needed: To subtract 4, remove 5 (heaven bead up), add 1
Result: 8 - 4 = 4 in ones, plus the 1 ten = 14

sections.text: Combined techniques sound complex when explained step-by-step, but with practice they become one fluid motion. The key is mastering 5-complement FIRST, so it becomes automatic when needed within a 10-complement operation.
From my professional experience, the soroban 10-complement offers unique developmental benefits:

items: Bilateral coordination: Both hands work together, crossing the midline
Visual-motor integration: Eyes track beads while fingers manipulate
Sequential processing: Children must hold multiple steps in working memory
Spatial reasoning: Understanding that columns represent different values
Proprioceptive feedback: The physical sensation of bead movement aids memory

sections.text: Based on my experience with my three children and the families I work with, here's the typical readiness timeline:

items: Prerequisite: Solid mastery of 5-complement (usually 4-8 weeks of practice)
Age range: Most children are ready between ages 6-8
Signs of readiness: Can do 5-complement without thinking, understands place value basics
Caution: Introducing too early leads to confusion and frustration
Individual variation: Some children are ready at 5, others not until 9
Mistake #1: Using 10-complement when not needed - Solution: Always check if result exceeds 9 (addition) or if there's enough to subtract
Mistake #2: Wrong complement pair - Solution: Drill pairs regularly, use finger counting to verify
Mistake #3: Forgetting to carry/borrow - Solution: Verbalize 'Add 10' or 'Borrow 10' while practicing
Mistake #4: Confusing 5 and 10 complements - Solution: Master 5-complement first, introduce 10-complement gradually
Mistake #5: Errors in combined techniques - Solution: Slow down, do each step deliberately until automatic
Use consistent language: 'Add 10, subtract complement' or 'Borrow 10, add complement'
Practice pairs verbally before using the soroban: 'What's 7's friend of 10?' '3!'
Start with problems that DON'T need 5-complement too (simpler first)
Use Sorokid's visual feedback - children can see immediately if they made an error
Celebrate small wins - each new complement pair mastered is an achievement
Be patient - this technique takes months, not weeks, to become automatic

sections.text: The combined 5 and 10 complement technique sounds complex, but with practice it becomes a single fluid motion. The brain automates the steps, and children eventually perform these calculations faster than they could ever do mental math without the soroban foundation.

faq.question: Should I teach 5-complement before 10-complement?
faq.answer: Yes, teaching 5-complement first is strongly recommended. The 5-complement is simpler because it operates within a single column, while 10-complement requires coordination across columns. Additionally, many 10-complement operations also require 5-complement within them (like our 8+6 example), so a solid 5-complement foundation makes learning 10-complement much smoother.

faq.question: This seems complicated. Will my child really learn this?
faq.answer: Absolutely! Children actually learn these patterns faster than adults because they haven't solidified other calculation methods yet. The soroban provides physical feedback that makes abstract concepts tangible. In my experience as both a therapist and mom, children who seemed 'bad at math' often excel with soroban because it engages different learning pathways.

faq.question: How long until complements become automatic?
faq.answer: With 15-20 minutes of daily practice, most children internalize the main 10-complement patterns within 2-3 months. Full automaticity - where combined 5 and 10 complement operations become instant - typically takes 4-6 months. The key is consistent daily practice rather than occasional long sessions.

faq.question: What is the 10-complement rule in soroban and why is it important?
faq.answer: The 10-complement rule is the soroban technique for handling calculations that cross column boundaries - carrying in addition and borrowing in subtraction. It uses number pairs that sum to 10 (1+9, 2+8, 3+7, etc.) to shift value between columns. This technique is essential because it enables multi-digit calculations and teaches place value in a tangible, visual way that traditional methods often fail to convey.

faq.question: What are all the 10-complement pairs I need to memorize?
faq.answer: There are nine 10-complement pairs: 1+9, 2+8, 3+7, 4+6, 5+5, 6+4, 7+3, 8+2, and 9+1. Note that five of these are mirrors of each other (1+9 and 9+1, etc.), so you really only need to learn five unique pairs. The 5+5 pair is unique and often the easiest to remember.

faq.question: How do I use 10-complement for addition with carrying on the soroban?
faq.answer: When adding two numbers would exceed 9 in a column: 1) Add 1 to the tens column (push up one earth bead in the column to the left), 2) Subtract the complement of the number you're adding from the ones column. For example, to add 7 to 8: add 1 to tens, subtract 3 (complement of 7) from ones. Result: 8-3=5 in ones, plus 10 = 15.

faq.question: How do I use 10-complement for subtraction with borrowing on the soroban?
faq.answer: When subtracting a number larger than what's in the ones column: 1) Subtract 1 from the tens column (pull down one earth bead in the column to the left), 2) Add the complement to the ones column. For example, to subtract 8 from 13: subtract 1 from tens (leaving 0), add 2 (complement of 8) to ones column. Result: 3+2=5.

faq.question: What's the difference between 5-complement and 10-complement?
faq.answer: The 5-complement operates within the SAME column using the heaven bead (worth 5). The 10-complement operates across DIFFERENT columns by carrying or borrowing (worth 10). 5-complement handles values within 0-9 of a single column; 10-complement handles values that would exceed 9 or go below 0 by involving the next column.

faq.question: When do I need to use both 5 and 10 complements together?
faq.answer: Combined techniques are needed when a 10-complement operation creates a secondary situation requiring 5-complement. For example, 8+6: The 10-complement requires subtracting 4 from 8, but 8-4 can't be done directly with earth beads (only 3 available). So you must use 5-complement (subtract 5, add 1) within the 10-complement operation. With practice, this becomes one fluid motion.

faq.question: What age should children start learning the 10-complement?
faq.answer: Most children are ready for 10-complement between ages 6-8, but the prerequisite is solid mastery of 5-complement (typically 4-8 weeks of practice). Signs of readiness include: performing 5-complement without conscious thought, understanding that digits have place values, and the ability to track two columns simultaneously. Some children are ready earlier, others later.

faq.question: How long does it take to master the 10-complement technique?
faq.answer: With consistent daily practice of 15-20 minutes, most children achieve basic competency with pure 10-complement operations within 2-3 months. Full automaticity including combined 5+10 complement operations typically takes 4-6 months. The Sorokid app's progressive difficulty system helps ensure children master each stage before advancing.

faq.question: Why is the soroban 10-complement better than traditional carrying and borrowing?
faq.answer: Traditional carrying/borrowing is often taught as a memorized procedure without true understanding. The soroban makes the exchange physically visible - children literally move beads between columns, seeing that 10 ones equals 1 ten. This builds genuine place value understanding and number sense that transfers to all math operations, including mental math without the soroban.

faq.question: How can I help my child practice 10-complement at home?
faq.answer: Effective strategies include: 1) Verbal pair drills ('What's 7's friend of 10?' '3!'), 2) Start with pure 10-complement problems before combined techniques, 3) Use consistent language ('Add 10, subtract complement'), 4) Celebrate mastery of each new pair, 5) Use Sorokid's gamified practice for engagement and instant feedback, 6) Keep sessions short (15-20 minutes) but consistent daily.
